verses.text: Therefore, having this ministry through the mercy that was given to us, we do not lose heart.
verses.comment: Paul’s perseverance comes from God's mercy. The 'ministry' refers to the apostolic work Paul was entrusted with. A reminder that perseverance in faith is a result of grace, not human effort alone.

verses.text: But we have renounced shameful hidden things, not walking in deceit or twisting God’s word, but by the open declaration of truth we commend ourselves to everyone’s conscience before God.
verses.comment: Paul contrasts his ministry with false teachers who distort scripture. There is an assertion of integrity and transparency in preaching, echoing the importance of tradition and clear teaching.

verses.text: And even if our gospel is veiled, it is veiled only to those who are perishing.
verses.comment: The 'veil' refers to spiritual blindness to the truth. Those who do not accept the message remain veiled; this recalls Paul’s words in the previous chapter about Israel’s veil before God’s glory.

verses.text: In their case, the god of this age has blinded the minds of unbelievers, so they do not see the light of the gospel of the glory of Christ, who is the image of God.
verses.comment: 'God of this age' refers to spiritual evil opposing Christ’s revelation. Christ as the 'image of God' affirms His divinity and perfect revelation (Col. 1:15). The light imagery also parallels John 1:4–9.

verses.text: For we do not preach ourselves, but Jesus Christ as Lord, and ourselves as your servants for Jesus’ sake.
verses.comment: Paul’s focus is Christ as Lord—a statement of His divine authority. Apostolic ministry is service, not self-glorification, recalling Jesus’ own instruction about servant leadership (Mark 10:45).

verses.text: For God, who said, 'Let light shine out of darkness,' has shone in our hearts to give the light of the knowledge of the glory of God in the face of Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: Paul references Genesis 1:3, connecting creation’s light to the revelation of God through Christ—the fullness of God’s revelation being visible in Christ’s face (John 14:9).

verses.text: But we have this treasure in jars of clay, to show that the surpassing power belongs to God and not to us.
verses.comment: 'Jars of clay' symbolize human frailty. The 'treasure' is God’s grace and revelation, placed in weak vessels to highlight God's power, not human achievement.

verses.text: We are afflicted in every way, but not crushed; perplexed, but not in despair;
verses.comment: Paul’s ministry endures suffering, yet demonstrates hope amidst adversity—a reflection of the Christian call to endure for the gospel and remain steadfast.

verses.text: persecuted, but not abandoned; struck down, but not destroyed;
verses.comment: Despite intense opposition, those who serve Christ endure by divine help. The assurance present here echoes Psalm 34:19 and Acts 14:22.

verses.text: always carrying in our body the dying of Jesus, so that the life of Jesus may also be revealed in our body.
verses.comment: Sharing in Christ’s sufferings is linked to experiencing His resurrected life (Romans 6:5). Paul connects apostolic suffering to participation in Christ’s death and life.

verses.text: For we who are alive are always being given over to death for Jesus’ sake, so that the life of Jesus might also be revealed in our mortal flesh.
verses.comment: The apostolic mission requires daily self-sacrifice, which paradoxically manifests Christ’s life in the believer. Christian tradition underscored this call to imitate Christ through the sacrificial example of the apostles.

verses.text: So death is at work in us, but life in you.
verses.comment: Paul’s sufferings bring spiritual life to others. This reflects the deep mystery of sacrificial ministry—how dying to self produces spiritual fruit in the Church.

verses.text: Since we have the same spirit of faith as it is written, 'I believed, and so I spoke,' we also believe, and therefore we also speak;
verses.comment: Paul cites Psalm 116:10, affirming that authentic faith is expressed verbally—public confession connects believers throughout history.

verses.text: knowing that He who raised the Lord Jesus will also raise us with Jesus and bring us into His presence together with you.
verses.comment: The resurrection hope unites believers with Christ and each other. This echoes the unity of the Church, a profound mystery that ties the faithful throughout time.

verses.text: For all these things are for your sake, so that as grace spreads to more and more people, thanksgiving may increase to the glory of God.
verses.comment: The work of ministry is for the benefit of the community, encouraging growth in thanksgiving—a foretaste of worship’s role in glorifying God.

verses.text: Therefore we do not lose heart. Though our outer self is wasting away, yet our inner self is being renewed day by day.
verses.comment: The contrast between physical decay and spiritual renewal is an encouragement. Daily renewal points toward the transformative power of the sacraments and personal prayer.

verses.text: For our light and momentary affliction is preparing for us an eternal weight of glory beyond all comparison.
verses.comment: The sufferings of this life are nothing compared with future glory—an encouragement for perseverance and hope, sustaining the community through trials.

verses.text: So we fix our eyes not on what is seen, but on what is unseen. For what is seen is temporary, but what is unseen is eternal.
verses.comment: This verse summarizes Christian hope in the unseen realities. Paul urges steadfast focus on spiritual truths, which echoes the necessity of faith and the promise of everlasting communion with God.
